questions.text: Which of the following conditions is a contraindication for radioactive iodine therapy?
questions.explanation:
Origin

It arises from the parafollicular 'C' cells, which are derived from the ultimobranchial body (neural crest).

Secrete

High levels of serum calcitonin and carcinoembryonic antigen

Types

2 types:

  • a) Sporadic: 80% cases, seen in 5th-6th decade, U/L
  • b) Familial: 20% cases, associated with MEN 2A/2B

Mutation

RET proto-oncogene mutation

Clinical features

Thyroid swelling often with enlargement of neck lymph nodes, diarrhea, flushing, hypertension, pheochromocytomas and mucosal neuromas when associated with MEN II syndrome.

Investigation of choice

FNAC

Treatment

  • Tumor localized to thyroid: total thyroidectomy + central neck dissection
  • + Ipsilateral MRND (If the tumor size is > 1
  • cm)
  • ± Bilateral MRND (If any lymph node is positive despite the extensive surgery).

Indications

Contraindications
  • Differentiated thyroid cancers

E.g., Papillary thyroid carcinoma (Option B)

Follicular thyroid carcinoma

Hurthle cell carcinoma (Option C)

  • Tumor size > 2 cm (Option D)
  • One or more risk factors
  • Obvious extrathyroidal extension
  • > 45 years of age
  • Lymph node and distant metastasis (Option D)
  • Poorly differentiated thyroid cancers

E.g., Medullary thyroid carcinoma

Anaplastic thyroid carcinoma

  • Pregnancy & Breastfeeding (Absolute contraindications)
  • Vomiting & Diarrhea (Relative contraindications)

A 40-year-old woman with a known history of Graves' disease presents with signs of thyroid storm i.e., fever, delirium, tachycardia, and restlessness. In addition to beta-blockers and antithyroid drugs, she is started on glucocorticoids. What is the primary rationale for administering glucocorticoids in the management of thyroid storm?

options.label: A
options.text: To block the conversion of T4 to T3

options.label: B
options.text: To suppress the synthesis of thyroid hormones

options.label: C
options.text: To reduce the effects of catecholamines

options.label: D
options.text: To block the release of T4 and T3

questions.correct_answer: A. To block the conversion of T4 to T3
questions.explanation:
Management of Thyroid storm
  • Oxygen supplementation
  • IV fluids (with continuous monitoring with central venous catheter)
  • Stop IV fluids/blood transfusion in case of CHF or arrhythmias

Propylthiouracil
  • This is the drug of choice
  • It acts by blocking the thyroid hormone synthesis & inhibiting peripheral conversion of T4 to T3 (Option B)
  • ROA: NG Tube, rectal route
  • Methimazole can be used as an alternative option instead of Propylthiouracil

Beta-blockers
  • Propranolol is commonly used
  • It reduces the heart rate & the effects of catecholamines (Option C)
  • Esmolol is used in case of heart failure as Propranolol should be avoided in such conditions

Glucocorticoids
  • Hydrocortisone is preferred
  • It acts by inhibiting the conversion of T4 to T3
  • It helps in preventing adrenal crisis

Lugol solution
  • It blocks the release of T3 and T4 and to reduce the vascularity of the thyroid (Option D)
  • It is also used preoperatively to prevent thyroid storms by inducing the Wolff-Chaikoff effect.

Cholestyramine

It is used to help sequester thyroid hormones.

Chlorpromazine

Used to induce sedation.

Plasmapheresis, charcoal plasma perfusion, or exchange transfusion are reserved for refractory cases that do not respond to standard treatment within 24 to 48 hours.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a history of multinodular goitre is being considered for thyroid surgery. Which of the following best describes this procedure?
questions.explanation:
Total Thyroidectomy

(Option A)
  • 2 × Lobectomy + Isthmusectomy
  • Requires lifelong thyroid hormone replacement therapy.

Subtotal Thyroidectomy

(Option D)
  • 2 × Subtotal Lobectomy + Isthmusectomy
  • Some functions are preserved with recurrence risk.
  • Only Indication - MNG in Elderly


Near-Total Thyroidectomy (Dunhill Procedure)

Lobectomy + Isthmusectomy + Subtotal Lobectomy


Lobectomy (Hemithyroidectomy)

(Option B)

Removal of one lobe of the thyroid gland + Isthmus
